title: Flight to Tokyo
helpfulInfo: Use Narita Express (included in JR Pass) to reach Shinjuku in ~75 min; stroll Omoide Yokocho for yakitori this evening.

title: Tokyo
highlights: Tokyo's oldest Buddhist temple Senso-ji, founded in the 7th century, with its iconic Kaminarimon Gate and giant red lantern; panoramic city views from Tokyo Skytree (634 m, the world's tallest tower); traditional Nakamise shopping street leading to Senso-ji offering local snacks and souvenirs.
helpfulInfo: The Senso-ji temple grounds are always open, but the main hall is generally accessible 6 AM–5 PM. Visit early or at night for a serene atmosphere with fewer crowds. Perform the cleansing ritual at the purification fountain before entering; modest attire is appreciated. Tokyo Skytree opens 10 AM–9 PM (last entry 8 PM). Book tickets in advance or visit on a weekday to avoid lines. Evening skyline views from the upper deck are spectacular, and Solamachi mall below has plenty of dining options.

title: Tokyo → Hakone
highlights: Meiji Jingu Shrine set in a peaceful 70-hectare forest dedicated to Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken; trendy Harajuku’s Takeshita Street for youth fashion, cosplay shops and colorful snacks; Shibuya Crossing, the world’s busiest pedestrian intersection with neon billboards and the famous Hachikō statue nearby.
helpfulInfo: Meiji Jingu is open from sunrise to sunset; cleanse at the temizuya and bow-clap-bow when praying. Takeshita Street shops open ~11 AM (weekdays are quieter). At Shibuya Crossing, watch from Starbucks or the Shibuya Sky deck. Afternoon Romancecar from Shinjuku to Hakone-Yumoto (Free Pass holders pay a small surcharge) gets you into the onsen region in 80–90 min; reserve seats online, and send larger luggage by takkyubin to your Hakone hotel if desired.

title: Hakone
highlights: Hakone, a scenic onsen resort area famed for views of Mount Fuji on clear days; Owakudani volcanic valley with sulfurous hot springs and black eggs boiled in mineral-rich waters; Lake Ashi where pirate-ship cruises offer picturesque lake vistas framed by Fuji; multiple hot-spring ryokans and bath houses for a relaxing onsen experience.
helpfulInfo: Purchase a Hakone Free Pass for unlimited rides on trains, buses, boats and ropeway. Follow onsen etiquette: wash thoroughly before soaking and keep towels out of the water. Many public baths restrict large tattoos—check ahead or book a private onsen. Weather changes quickly—Fuji often hides in clouds—so aim for an early cruise or ropeway ride, and keep the Hakone Open-Air Museum as a great rain option.

title: Hakone → Kyoto
highlights: Fushimi Inari Taisha with its thousands of vermilion torii gates winding up Mt. Inari; Kiyomizu-dera Temple (UNESCO) with its huge wooden terrace overlooking the city; historic Higashiyama lanes lined with traditional shops and teahouses, preserving old-Kyoto atmosphere.
helpfulInfo: Fushimi Inari is open 24/7; dawn or dusk visits avoid crowds. The full summit loop takes 2-3 h; turning around at Yotsutsuji still grants city views. Kiyomizu-dera opens 6 AM; arrive early to beat tour buses. Higashiyama shops close by 6–7 PM—try yatsuhashi sweets and respect ‘no-smoking-while-walking’ rules in Kyoto’s old streets.

title: Kyoto
highlights: Arashiyama Bamboo Grove; Tenryu-ji Temple-garden (UNESCO); Kinkaku-ji (Golden Pavilion) reflecting in its pond.
helpfulInfo: Visit the bamboo grove at sunrise for solitude; Tenryu-ji garden opens 8:30 AM (¥500). Kinkaku-ji opens 9 AM; go at opening or just before closing to avoid the heaviest crowds. Allow travel time between Arashiyama and Kinkaku-ji (≈40 min by bus or taxi).

title: Kyoto
highlights: Gion & Pontocho, Kyoto’s historic geisha quarters packed with lantern-lit machiya townhouses and teahouses; Nijo-jo Castle (UNESCO), the Tokugawa shogun’s 17th-century residence famous for ‘nightingale floors’ and opulent screen paintings; Nishiki Market, a 400-year-old covered arcade nicknamed “Kyoto’s Kitchen” where 130 stalls sell pickles, yuba, wagashi sweets and other local delicacies.
helpfulInfo: Arrive at Nijo-jo when it opens at 8 :45 AM (last entry 4 PM, ¥1 300); shoes must be removed inside the palace. Nishiki Market livens up from 10 AM and winds down ~6 PM—sample freely but keep moving in the narrow lane. Early evening, stroll Hanamikoji Street in Gion; photograph maiko/geiko from a respectful distance without blocking their path. Cross Shijo Bridge to tiny Pontocho alley for kaiseki or yakitori (some restaurants charge cover).

title: Kyoto
highlights: Philosopher’s Path (Tetsugaku-no-michi), a tranquil 2 km canal walk lined with cherry trees and temples; Ginkaku-ji (Silver Pavilion) with its raked ‘Sea of Silver Sand’ garden; Nanzen-ji temple district featuring a soaring brick aqueduct and moss-filled sub-temple gardens.
helpfulInfo: Enter Ginkaku-ji at its 8:30 AM opening (¥500) to enjoy the gardens in peace. The Philosopher’s Path takes 30–40 min at a gentle pace; drop into Honen-in or Otoyo-jinja en route. Nanzen-ji’s free grounds never close; paid areas like the Hojo Garden and Sanmon Gate shut 4:30 PM (¥600 each). From Nanzen-ji, Keage subway returns downtown in 10 min or walk to Heian Shrine.

title: Kyoto → Hiroshima
highlights: Ride the Shinkansen from Kyoto to Hiroshima (≈1 h 40 min) passing Lake Biwa and Himeji; stroll 17th-century Shukkeien Garden with its miniature landscapes and tea pavilions; evening in Hondori arcade tasting Hiroshima-style okonomiyaki at Okonomimura and catching sunset city views from Orizuru Tower beside the Peace Memorial Park.
helpfulInfo: Reserve Shinkansen seats (right-side windows for a fleeting Mount Fuji glimpse soon after Yokohama). Hiroshima’s Meipuru-pu loop-bus day-pass costs ¥600 and stops at Shukkeien and Peace Park. Shukkeien opens 9 AM–6 PM (to 5 PM Nov–Feb, ¥260). Okonomimura stalls open 11 AM–late; expect ~¥1 200 per pancake. Orizuru Tower observation deck 10 AM–7 PM (¥1 700) has origami-crane activities.

title: Hiroshima
highlights: Peace Memorial Museum and Atomic Bomb Dome in Hiroshima’s Peace Park (UNESCO World Heritage); Miyajima Island’s ‘floating’ vermilion torii of Itsukushima Shrine, roaming deer and Seto Inland Sea vistas.
helpfulInfo: The museum opens 7:30 AM–6 PM (¥200); allow 1–2 h and keep voices low. JR ferries to Miyajima every 15 min (10 min ride, covered by Rail Pass). Check tide tables—at high tide the torii appears to float; at low tide you can walk out to its base.

title: Hiroshima → Kanazawa
helpfulInfo: Kenroku-en is free before 7 AM; pair with Kanazawa Castle via Ishikawa Gate. The Kanazawa Loop-Bus day-pass is ¥600.

title: Kanazawa
helpfulInfo: In Nagamachi samurai district visit Nomura-ke with English audio; try gold-leaf ice cream in Higashi-Chaya.

title: Kanazawa → Tokyo
helpfulInfo: Reserve a window seat on the Kagayaki Shinkansen for Sea-of-Japan views the first 30 min; send bags to your airport hotel via takuhaibin.

title: Tokyo
highlights: Meiji-Schrein – https://www.japan-guide.com/e/e3002.html ; Harajuku – https://www.japan-guide.com/e/e3006.html ; Shibuya – https://www.japan-guide.com/e/e3007.html
helpfulInfo: Meiji Shrine opens at dawn; after Harajuku crepes, pre-book Shibuya Sky sunset slot online.

title: Tokyo → Kanagawa
helpfulInfo: Pay ¥50 to enter Kamakura’s Great Buddha; ride Yokohama’s Cosmo Clock 17 after dark for skyline photos.

title: Yokohama
helpfulInfo: Book a private tea room in Sankeien Garden (¥3 000/hr) and a sunset cruise from Osanbashi pier (1 h).

title: Yokohama → Tokyo
helpfulInfo: Use the Metro 24-h ticket (¥600) for unlimited rides; consider teamLab Borderless in Azabudai Hills (opened 2024).

title: Flight to Hawaii
helpfulInfo: Check-in opens three hours before departure; airport Muji is great for last-minute gifts.
